headline: Trump says Intel CEO has an 'amazing story' days after calling for his resignation
summary: Less than a week after demanding his resignation, President Donald Trump is now calling the career of Intel's CEO an “amazing story.”  Shares of Intel, which slid last week after CEO Lip-Bu Tan came under fire from the U.S. president, bounced higher before the opening bell Tuesday.  The attack from Trump came after Sen. Tom Cotton sent a letter to Intel Chairman Frank Yeary expressing concern over Tan’s investments and ties to semiconductor firms that are reportedly linked to the Chinese Communist Party and the People’s Liberation Army.

headline: Forget the White House Sideshow. Intel Must Decide What It Wants to Be.
summary: Five months in and Lip-Bu Tan is already fighting for his job.  The identity question—whether Intel wants to be a chip designer, a manufacturer, or remain both of those things—was possible to gloss over in Tan’s early days as chief executive.  President Trump last week took the unprecedented step of publicly calling for Tan to resign.

headline: Trump Met With Intel CEO, Says Tan Will Bring ‘Suggestions’ Next Week
summary: After meeting with  Intel  CEO Lip-Bu Tan Monday, President Donald Trump struck a more conciliatory tone than he had last week when he called for Tan’s resignation.  “The meeting was a very interesting one,” Trump posted to Truth Social.  Trump had called for Tan to resign in a post last Thursday, saying the Intel CEO was “highly conflicted,” following a letter sent by Republican Sen. Tom Cotton questioning Tan’s links to Chinese firms.

raw.headline: Trump Met With Intel CEO, Says Tan Will Bring ‘Suggestions’ Next Week

Trump had called for Tan to resign in a post last Thursday, saying the Intel CEO was “highly conflicted,” following a letter sent by Republican Sen. Tom Cotton questioning Tan’s links to Chinese firms.

headline: Trump praises Intel CEO days after calling for him to resign
summary: STORY: U.S. President Donald Trump said he met with Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan on Monday, praising him and calling the meeting "a very interesting one".That's a reversal days after Trump publicly called for Tan to resign, claiming he was "highly conflicted" over ties to Chinese firms, raising doubts about Tan's plans to turn around the struggling American chip icon.In a post on Truth Social Monday, Trump said he met with Tan, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.In the post, Trump also said his cabinet members and Tan were going to bring "suggestions" to him next week.He added that Tan's "success and rise is an amazing story".According to Reuters' reporting in April, Tan had invested in hundreds of Chinese firms.Some of those were linked to the Chinese military.It is not illegal for U.S. citizens to hold stakes in Chinese companies unless the firms have been explicitly banned on a U.S. Treasury list.An Intel statement Monday said Tan met with Trump for a candid and constructive discussion on the company's commitment to strengthening U.S. technology and manufacturing leadership.It also said the firm would work closely with the administration to "restore this great American company".

raw.headline: Trump praises Intel CEO days after calling for him to resign
raw.summary: STORY: U.S. President Donald Trump said he met with Intel CEO Lip-Bu Tan on Monday, praising him and calling the meeting "a very interesting one".That's a reversal days after Trump publicly called for Tan to resign, claiming he was "highly conflicted" over ties to Chinese firms, raising doubts about Tan's plans to turn around the struggling American chip icon.In a post on Truth Social Monday, Trump said he met with Tan, Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.In the post, Trump also said his cabinet members and Tan were going to bring "suggestions" to him next week.He added that Tan's "success and rise is an amazing story".According to Reuters' reporting in April, Tan had invested in hundreds of Chinese firms.Some of those were linked to the Chinese military.It is not illegal for U.S. citizens to hold stakes in Chinese companies unless the firms have been explicitly banned on a U.S. Treasury list.An Intel statement Monday said Tan met with Trump for a candid and constructive discussion on the company's commitment to strengthening U.S. technology and manufacturing leadership.It also said the firm would work closely with the administration to "restore this great American company".
